Award.AwardTitle: The Biographies of Scientific Ideas: What the Content and Structure of Citations Reveal About the Diffusion of Knowledge

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Currently, more than a million scholarly articles are published per year. Understanding how these journal articles, often the primary unit of scientific research, are consumed over time by the scientific community is essential to understanding the production and dissemination of knowledge. Conventionally, the main strategy used to gauge the impact of scientific research is to count the number of citations received. The central problem with this approach is that citation counts do not distinguish between the context of the citation (e.g., the difference between positive, critical, and symbolic) nor do they consider the source of the citation (e.g., the difference between 100 detailed references from area experts and 100 ceremonial mentions from non-specialists). Citation counts thus reveal very little about how researchers actually use and interpret existing knowledge, which directly impedes our ability to meaningfully gauge the impact of scientific research. This project develops new insight into how knowledge accumulates by systematically examining how a set of seed publications are incorporated, distilled, and expanded upon by a set of potentially connected citing publications. This entails compiling a large, longitudinal dataset of focal articles and their citation histories, which will then be analyzed as life histories. The methodological strategy is a unique combination of quantitative and qualitative approaches (citation context analysis, co-citation analysis, citation network analysis) that allows for the "thick description" of issues related to time, interpretation, audience, and disciplinary context.

This project focuses on a large sample of flagship journal articles from two disciplines: sociology and medicine. The results will thus inform long-standing questions about how knowledge accumulates in the 'hard' versus 'soft' sciences. In addition, studying the diffusion and incorporation of medical findings has practical implications for health policy makers, addressing recent claims that clinical research studies typically go unchallenged in the medical research community. Finally, the data generated from this project create new opportunities to study the diffusion of innovations, networks, and social influence. First, by following a cohort of papers published at the same time, the research avoids retrospective sampling on "winning" innovations. Second, for each seed article, the timeline and connectedness of its adopters can be directly mapped via direct citation links as well as co-citation links. Third, unlike most kinds of adoption data (e.g., sales data), citation choices give us some insight into how an innovation was adopted. The content of the citation provides new data on whether some citers are more influential than others in publicizing certain aspects of an innovation.

Broader Impacts
This historical study is designed to produce new insights into what advancement in science actually entails. Examining how ideas are used and incorporated provides a foundation for evaluating the logic and efficiency of knowledge accumulation in science. In the long-term, these insights will enable the development of metrics that describe the use-value of the myriad "new" ideas put forth each year in science. The project thus facilitates the creation of new empirically grounded tools that science and innovation policy makers can use to gauge the scientific impact of research publications and individual scholars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this research project, the PIs uncovered new insights regarding the diffusion of ideas in science. More than a million scholarly articles are published per year and yet researchers and science policy-makers know relatively little about how knowledge is consumed post-publication. The traditional strategy used to gauge the impact of scientific research is to count the number of citations a publication receives. The central problem with this approach, however, is that the number of citations does not reveal anything about the context of those citations or the source of those citations. For example, an article that is positively engaged by an area expert counts as having the same impact as an article that is referenced only in passing by a non-specialist.

 

Thus, to broaden our understanding of how ideas are incorporated and evolve through citations, we assembled a longitudinal dataset of articles published in top journals from multiple fields and their citation histories. In addition, for a subsample of sociology articles, we hand coded over 3000 citations to 100 different articles. We considered the context of the citation holistically but also tracked, for example, the section of the article in which the citation appears, whether the authors were mentioned directly in a sentence or cited only parenthetically, as well as whether the focal authors quoted passages or phrases from the authors being cited.

 

The first study to result from this project documents the diffusion of papers across disciplinary boundaries in six different fields (cell biology, economics, mathematics, philosophy, political science, and sociology). The empirical analysis, which spans 13 flagship journals, was based on over 800 articles and the 55,000+ citations they accumulate over a 20-year period. The resulting dataset led to new insights on diffusion patterns in science: in general, articles published in a field’s flagship journals are first adopted by high visibility journals from within the focal discipline and then, to varying degrees, spread out over time to journals of all prestige levels from a variety of disciplines. In addition, this paper (a) documented that outside audiences were more sensitive to status cues than inside audiences, and (b) explored the implications of this (micro) behavioral pattern for understanding citation inequality at the journal level.

 

This insider-to-outsider and high-to-low pattern underscores that the sum of attention is often composed of heterogeneous sources of attention, which pushes science policy experts to start thinking more critically about the nature of an audience, rather than just its size. We typically equate the size of an article’s following with importance, but a “following” can clearly vary in qualitatively different ways. To illustrate this point, the second paper from this project offers an in-depth exploration of four distinct incorporation pathways. For this paper, we employ a unique methodological strategy that combines quantitative and qualitative approaches (citation context analysis, co-citation analysis, network analysis) that allows for the "thick description" of issues related to time, interpretation, audience, and disciplinary context. Focusing on four case studies from sociology, we show how articles vary not only in terms of audience size (e.g., 3000 versus 30 citations) but also audience structure and composition (e.g., a densely connected audience of citers who are all experts in one area versus a loosely connected group of followers from a variety of disciplines). For each case, we discuss how a sequence of adopters comes to change and define the original innovation.

 

In summary, this historical project has produced new insights into what advancement in science actually entails. Importantly, because we follow a cohort of papers published at the same time, the research avoids retrospective sampling on "winning" innovations. Not only does this advance our understanding of diffusion dynamics in general, the project provides new leads on what science and innovation policy should take into account when designing metrics intended to describe the use-value of the myriad "new" ideas put forth each year in science.
